results.title: China's chair
results.creator_credit: Gilbert Lauzun, Edward Magruder Jones and United Nations Television
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “International Zone”.
Offers the controversial slice of history that makes up the years 1945-1971, on the China question in the United Nations, ending with the People’s Republic of China being seated in the General Assembly on November 15, 1971. Includes footage of Russia’s walkout from the Security Council to protest the continued Nationalist presence, the United Nations intervention in Korea, and the appearance of General Wu of the People’s Republic. Contains black and white sequences. Narrated by Donald Pringle.

results.title: China
results.creator_credit: Colin Baker, Australia. Special Broadcasting Service and Cinegroup
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “A Travellers’ guide to the Orient”.
China is the world’s longest continuous civilisation and the country is rich with ancient artefacts and sites. The opening of China to tourism by its Communist rulers has meant that this nation of over one billion people is now a popular tourist attraction. This video begins in the capital of Beijing where we witness the marvels of the Forbidden City and the Temple of Heaven. From there we travel to Xian and follow the Silk Road to Lanzhou, and visit a Buddhist monastery. From there onwards we travel across the stark Gobi Desert. This video is an excellent introduction to the landscape and vast diversity of China.

results.title: Chimpanzees reared in darkness
results.creator_credit: Psychological Cinema Register and Pennsylvania State University
results.brief_description: Compares two chimpanzees that have been in complete darkness from birth to 18 months with normally reared infants. The experimental chimpanzees show a lack of visual fixations, absence of object recognition, and failure to discriminate familiar from strange persons. The chimpanzees present nystagmus of the blind and slowness of visual learning, with inaccuracies in reaching movements and dependence on tactual and kinesthetic cues, in contrast to the dependence on visual cues in normal infants. Silent film with English subtext.

results.title: Chillysmith farm
results.creator_credit: Valley Filmworks, Mark Jury and Dan Jury
results.brief_description: Chillysmith Farm was the home of Gramp, whose last years were documented by his grandsons in the photo essay ‘Gramp’. In this film, 10 years in the making, Gramp and other members of his family are shown. Birth and death are shown by the whole family. This is a film for all ages that raises issues of family life, birth, death, and individual responsibility of the ageing.

results.title: Chillida
results.creator_credit: William Leeson, Laurence Boulting, ETB Euskal Telebista (Basque Television) and RM Arts
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Phaidon art collection”.
This is a fine introduction to the work of renowned Basque sculptor Eduardo Chillida (born 1914), who works mainly with iron, clay, and stone to create both monumental and smaller works of art. Chillida’s art is primarily conceptual and not functional. We learn through his articulate commentary that Chillida is interested in space, time and the unknown. He begins the creative process without imposing preconceived thoughts, aims or ideas. Rather, Chillida seeks to break away from tradition, habit, expectation and repetition to discover and enter the unknown, the unseen. His approach is philosophical, and the result is impressive. The documentary also provides an overview of Chillida’s childhood, family background, his affinity with his hometown San Sebastian, and his working methods. The local history and traditions of his hometown are an important influence on his work as is its natural wonders. The abstract minimalism of Chillida’s art is spiritual, and a wondrous attempt to grapple with the mysteries and beauty of the world of nature.

results.title: Chilean nitrate: gift of the desert
results.brief_description: Visualises the mining, refining and transportation of nitrate of soda in the Attacama Desert of Northern Chile. Tells of the discovery of the deposits by two American Indians. Shows the magnitude of refining operations in the area, stressing the isolation that employees of the industry must face. Describes a new form in which the nitrate can be readily stored in ships. States the importance of the industry to Chile.
results.description: Visualises the mining, refining and transportation of nitrate of soda in the Attacama Desert of Northern Chile. Tells of the discovery of the deposits by two American Indians. States the importance of the industry to Chile.

results.title: Chilean hacienda: a traditional farm estate
results.creator_credit: Hollywood Film Enterprises and Clifford J. Kamen
results.brief_description: A relatively small part of Chile is suitable for farming but in this part are large farm estates, many owned by the descendants of the Spaniards who originally settled there. Employing as many as 1,000 employees, each hacienda will have its own shopping centre, school, and hospital. The employees give some of their time in payment for housing etc and also receive wages. The products are wheat, fruit, cattle, potatoes, and similar farm products. Amusements include dancing and rodeos. The haciendas are the core of the farming system of an agricultural nation.

results.title: Chile: hasta cuando?(Captioned)
results.brief_description: An account of the political unrest in Chile, 12 years after the murder of Allende and the installation of military dictatorship under General Pinochet. This powerful documentary is also about the struggle of the people of Chile. Under the dictatorship of Pinochet some 50,000 Chileans were detained, many are missing believed dead.
